trial_identification.studytitle: Mobility of the hip and knee joints in obese children
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Range of motion of the hip and knee joints of obese and eutrophic children: a comparative study

interventions.interventions: Goniometry was performed in hip flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, external rotation and internal rotation, and in knee flexion. For the intra-assessor reliability, the assessor number 1 performed the measurements of the 50 subjects twice (30 eutrophic and 20 obese), which were compared among them. For the inter-assessor reliability, the assessor number 2 performed the measurements of the 50 subjects (30 eutrophic and 20 obese) once, which were compared with the measurements of the assessor number 1 to obtain inter-assessor reliability. The time interval among the 3 measures performed by the assessors was at least 1 week, and at last 1 month.
interventions.comparator: The hip and knee range of motion of obese/overweight children will be compared with a group of eutrophic children.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Hip and knee range of motion using a goniometer.
Reliability (intra-assessor reliability and inter-assessor reliability) of the goniometric measurements of hip and knee joints
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Time interval was at least 1 week, and at last 1 month

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: The Body mass index (BMI) of obese or overweight children had to be above the 85 percentage of the Body mass index (BMI) by age distribution graphic of the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS), while for the group of eutrophic children, the values had to be under the 85 percentage.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Children with joint hypermobility, metabolical diseases, musculoskeletal diseases, neurological diseases, lower limbs recent injury, and children who practice institutionalized sport or physical exercise in addition to the physical activity proposed by the school in a frequency greater than twice a week and/or greater than 3 hours per week

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Obesity can be defined as the excessive and generalized accumulation of fat in the subcutaneous tissue and in other tissues, being able to damage health. The excess of fat mass and the overload on the major joints may evolve to pain, discomfort, inefficient biomechanics and consequent mobility reductions. The objective of this research was to assess the hip and knee range of motion of obese/overweight children, and compare them with a group of eutrophic children.
